recipes.name: Bisi Bele Bath
recipes.description: A wholesome and aromatic one-pot meal made with rice, lentils, vegetables, and a special spice powder. A signature Karnataka comfort food.

steps.instruction: Pressure cook rice and toor dal together with 3 cups water until soft and mushy (about 4 whistles).
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract the juice.
Cook mixed vegetables until tender. You can pressure cook or boil them.
Mash the cooked rice-dal mixture well. Add tamarind juice, bisi bele bath powder, jaggery, and salt.
Add cooked vegetables and mix everything well. Cook on medium heat for 10 minutes, adding water if needed.
In a small pan, heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, cashews, and curry leaves. Fry until cashews are golden.
Pour the tempering over the bisi bele bath and mix well. Serve hot with a dollop of ghee and papad.

tips: The dish should have a porridge-like consistency
Adjust spice powder quantity based on your preference
Leftovers taste even better the next day

recipes.name: Ragi Mudde
recipes.description: Traditional finger millet balls - a staple food of Karnataka. Highly nutritious and typically served with sambar or non-veg curries.

steps.instruction: Boil 2 cups of water with salt in a heavy-bottomed pan.
Reduce heat to low. Slowly add ragi flour while stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Keep stirring vigorously for 5-7 minutes until the mixture comes together and leaves the sides of the pan.
Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
Wet your hands with water and shape the mixture into round balls.

tips: Keep stirring to avoid lumps
The dough should be smooth and not sticky
Serve immediately while hot

recipes.name: Mysore Masala Dosa
recipes.description: Crispy dosa spread with spicy red chutney and filled with potato masala. A famous breakfast from Mysore.

steps.instruction: Boil potatoes until soft, peel and mash them coarsely.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add curry leaves and green chilies.
Add sliced onions and sauté until translucent. Add turmeric and mashed potatoes.
Mix well, season with salt, and keep the filling warm.
Heat a dosa tawa. Pour batter and spread in circular motion to make thin dosa.
Spread red chutney on the dosa. Add potato filling in the center.
Add butter, fold the dosa, and serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

tips: The dosa should be crispy and golden
Red chutney gives the authentic Mysore taste
Use a well-seasoned iron tawa for best results

recipes.name: Akki Rotti
recipes.description: Rice flour flatbread with onions, carrots, and fresh herbs. A popular Karnataka breakfast.

steps.instruction: Finely chop onion, grate carrot, chop green chilies and coriander leaves.
Mix rice flour, chopped vegetables, coconut, cumin, curry leaves, and salt in a bowl.
Add warm water gradually and knead into a soft dough (should not be sticky).
Take a ball of dough and pat it on a greased banana leaf or plastic sheet into a thin circle.
Heat a tawa, transfer the rotti and cook on medium heat. Add oil around edges.
Flip when bottom is golden and cook the other side until crispy.

tips: The dough should be soft but not sticky
Pat with wet hands for easier shaping
Cook on medium heat for even cooking

recipes.name: Neer Dosa
recipes.description: Delicate, lacy rice crepes from Mangalore. Light as water (neer), these dosas are perfect with coconut chutney.

steps.instruction: Soak rice for 4-6 hours or overnight.
Grind soaked rice with coconut and salt adding water to make a thin, watery batter.
The batter should be very thin, like buttermilk consistency.
Heat a non-stick pan on medium-high heat. Do not grease it.
Pour batter from a height and let it spread naturally into a lacy pattern.
Cover and cook for 1-2 minutes. No need to flip. Dosa will be white and soft.

tips: No fermentation needed for this dosa
The batter must be very thin
Cook on a non-stick pan without oil

recipes.name: Chicken Ghee Roast
recipes.description: Iconic Mangalorean dish with succulent chicken pieces cooked in aromatic spices and generous amounts of ghee.

steps.instruction: Dry roast red chilies, coriander, cumin, pepper, and fenugreek until fragrant. Cool and grind with garlic and tamarind to a paste.
Marinate chicken pieces with half the paste and salt for 30 minutes.
Heat ghee in a heavy pan. Add sliced onions and fry until golden.
Add marinated chicken and cook on high heat for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add remaining paste and curry leaves. Cook covered on medium heat for 15 minutes.
Uncover and roast on high heat until the ghee separates and chicken is well coated with masala.

tips: Use good quality ghee for authentic taste
The final dish should be dry, not gravy-like
Byadgi chilies give color without too much heat

recipes.name: Jolada Rotti
recipes.description: Sorghum flatbread, a staple of North Karnataka. Best enjoyed with spicy chutneys and curries.

steps.instruction: Add salt to jowar flour and mix well.
Add hot water gradually and knead into a soft, pliable dough.
Divide into 4 portions and shape into balls.
Pat each ball on a wet cloth or banana leaf into a circle about 6-7 inches.
Heat tawa. Transfer rotti and cook on medium heat for 2-3 minutes per side.
Can be roasted directly on flame for charred flavor.

tips: The water must be hot to bind the flour
Pat with wet hands to prevent sticking
Best served hot off the tawa

recipes.name: Ennegai
recipes.description: Stuffed brinjal curry from North Karnataka. Baby eggplants stuffed with spicy peanut-coconut masala.

steps.instruction: Make slits in brinjals keeping stem intact. Soak in water to prevent browning.
Dry roast red chilies and grind with peanuts, coconut, tamarind, garlic, jaggery, and salt.
Stuff the masala paste into the brinjal slits. Reserve leftover masala.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Place stuffed brinjals in the pan. Cover and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally.
Add remaining masala with a little water. Cook until brinjals are tender and masala coats them.

tips: Use small, tender brinjals for best results
Cook on low heat for even cooking
The masala should be slightly sweet and tangy

recipes.name: Kane Fish Fry
recipes.description: Crispy fried ladyfish, a beloved coastal Karnataka delicacy. Marinated in spices and shallow fried to perfection.

steps.instruction: Clean the fish, make diagonal slits on both sides.
Grind garlic with red chili powder, turmeric, tamarind, and salt to make a paste.
Apply the paste all over the fish, including inside the slits. Marinate for 30 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan. Shallow fry fish on medium heat for 4-5 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot with onion rings and lemon wedges.

tips: Fresh fish tastes best
Marinate for at least 30 minutes for flavor to penetrate
Don't flip too often while frying

recipes.name: Holige / Obbattu
recipes.description: Sweet stuffed flatbread made with chana dal filling. A festive Karnataka specialty.

steps.instruction: Cook chana dal until soft. Drain well and mash.
Add jaggery to warm dal and cook until jaggery melts and mixture thickens. Add cardamom.
Cool the filling and divide into 8 portions.
Make soft dough with flour, turmeric, salt, oil, and water. Rest for 15 minutes.
Divide dough into 8 balls. Roll each, place filling, seal, and roll gently into a thin circle.
Cook on medium heat tawa with ghee until golden on both sides.

tips: The filling should not be too wet
Roll gently to prevent filling from coming out
Serve warm with generous ghee

recipes.name: Vangi Bath
recipes.description: Spiced brinjal rice, a popular Karnataka rice dish with tangy and spicy flavors.

steps.instruction: Cut brinjal into small cubes and soak in water.
Heat oil, add mustard seeds and curry leaves. Let splutter.
Add brinjal cubes and fry until soft and slightly browned.
Add vangi bath powder, tamarind, jaggery, and salt. Mix well.
Add cooked rice and peanuts. Mix gently until well combined.
Cover and cook on low heat for 5 minutes. Serve with raita.

tips: Use day-old rice for best results
Don't overcook the brinjal
Adjust tamarind and jaggery to balance flavors

recipes.name: Saaru / Karnataka Rasam
recipes.description: Karnataka-style rasam with a distinct flavor profile. Lighter than Tamil rasam with more tomato tang.

steps.instruction: Blend tomatoes and extract tamarind juice.
Combine tomato puree, tamarind juice, dal water, rasam powder, turmeric, jaggery, and salt in a pot.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes until flavors blend.
In a small pan, heat ghee. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Pour the tempering over rasam. Add chopped coriander and serve hot.

tips: Don't boil for too long after adding tamarind
The rasam should be thin and soupy
Best served as first course with rice

recipes.name: Uddina Vada
recipes.description: Crispy urad dal fritters, a South Indian classic. Perfect with coconut chutney and sambar.

steps.instruction: Soak urad dal for 3-4 hours. Drain well.
Grind to a thick, fluffy batter using minimal water. The batter should be airy.
Add chopped chilies, ginger, curry leaves, pepper, cumin, and salt. Mix well.
Heat oil for deep frying. Wet your hands, take a portion of batter, shape into a disc with a hole in center.
Gently slide into hot oil. Fry on medium heat until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels. Serve hot with chutney and sambar.

tips: The batter should be thick and airy, not watery
Fry on medium heat for crispy outside and soft inside
Add a few grains of rice while grinding for extra crispiness

recipes.name: Rava Idli
recipes.description: Instant semolina idlis invented at MTR, Bangalore. Quick to make with no fermentation required.

steps.instruction: Heat ghee in a pan. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves, cashews, green chilies, and ginger. Sauté.
Add rava and roast on low heat for 5 minutes until slightly golden.
Cool the rava. Mix with curd, water, and salt to form a thick batter.
Just before steaming, add Eno and mix gently.
Pour into greased idli moulds immediately.
Steam for 10-12 minutes. Check with toothpick for doneness.

tips: Add Eno just before steaming for fluffy idlis
The batter should be thick, not runny
Steam immediately after adding Eno

recipes.name: Paddu / Gundponglu
recipes.description: Round fluffy dumplings made from dosa batter, cooked in a special pan. A favorite Karnataka snack.

steps.instruction: Heat paddu/appe pan and add a few drops of oil in each mould.
Pour batter to fill 3/4 of each mould.
Add a small piece of onion and coconut on top if desired.
Cover and cook on medium-low heat for 3-4 minutes.
Flip using a fork or spoon and cook the other side for 2-3 minutes.
Remove when golden brown on all sides. Serve hot with chutney.

tips: Use well-fermented batter for fluffy paddus
Don't overcrowd the moulds
Cook on medium-low heat for even cooking

recipes.name: Kosambari
recipes.description: Refreshing moong dal salad with cucumber and coconut. A must-have in Karnataka festivals.

steps.instruction: Soak moong dal for 1 hour. Drain well.
Finely chop cucumber and green chili. Grate coconut.
Combine dal, cucumber, coconut, chili, and coriander in a bowl.
Add lemon juice and salt. Mix well.
Heat oil, add mustard seeds. When they splutter, pour over the salad.
Toss gently and serve immediately.

tips: Don't oversoak the dal - it should be crunchy
Add lemon juice just before serving
Can add pomegranate seeds for variation

recipes.name: Chitranna / Lemon Rice
recipes.description: Tangy lemon rice with aromatic tempering. A popular temple prasadam and travel-friendly meal.

steps.instruction: Spread cooked rice on a plate and let it cool. Break any lumps.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let splutter.
Add urad dal, chana dal, and fry until golden.
Add red chilies, green chilies, curry leaves, and peanuts. Sauté briefly.
Add turmeric and asafoetida. Remove from heat.
Add rice to the pan, pour lemon juice, and add salt. Mix gently until evenly coated.

tips: Use day-old rice for best texture
Add lemon juice after removing from heat to retain freshness
Can be stored at room temperature for hours

recipes.name: Shavige Payasa
recipes.description: Traditional vermicelli kheer made with milk and jaggery. A classic Karnataka dessert.

steps.instruction: Heat ghee in a pan. Roast vermicelli until golden brown.
Add cashews and fry until golden. Set aside.
Boil milk in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add roasted vermicelli.
Cook until vermicelli is soft, stirring occasionally.
In a separate pan, melt jaggery with a little water. Strain and add to the payasa.
Add cardamom, coconut, and cashews. Serve warm or chilled.

tips: Roast vermicelli well for nutty flavor
Add jaggery after milk to prevent curdling
Can be served warm or cold

recipes.name: Mangalorean Fish Curry
recipes.description: Coconut-based fish curry from Mangalore. Tangy, spicy, and full of coastal flavors.

steps.instruction: Clean fish and cut into pieces. Apply salt and turmeric.
Dry roast red chilies, coriander, cumin, and fenugreek until fragrant.
Grind roasted spices with coconut, garlic, and tamarind to a smooth paste using water.
Heat oil in a clay pot or pan. Add the ground masala and sauté for 3-4 minutes.
Add water to get desired curry consistency. Add kokum and salt. Bring to boil.
Gently add fish pieces. Simmer for 8-10 minutes until fish is cooked. Don't stir too much.

tips: Use clay pot for authentic taste
Don't stir too much to prevent fish from breaking
Let the curry rest for 10 minutes for flavors to develop

recipes.name: Mutton Donne Biryani
recipes.description: Bangalore's famous biryani served in leaf cups (donne). Spicy, flavorful, and uniquely Bangalore.

ingredients.name: Whole spices (bay leaf, cloves, cardamom, cinnamon)

steps.instruction: Wash and soak rice for 30 minutes. Marinate mutton with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, biryani masala, mint, coriander, and salt.
Heat oil and ghee in a heavy-bottomed pot. Add whole spices and sliced onions. Fry until deep golden.
Add marinated mutton and green chilies. Cook on high heat for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add chopped tomatoes. Cook covered on low heat until mutton is 80% done (about 25-30 minutes).
Par-boil rice with whole spices until 70% cooked. Drain and layer over the mutton.
Seal the pot with dough or foil. Cook on very low heat (dum) for 20 minutes.
Open and gently mix layers. Serve in donne (leaf cups) with raita.

tips: Marinate mutton for at least 2 hours for best flavor
The dum process is crucial - don't open too early
Use good quality basmati rice

recipes.name: Majjige Huli
recipes.description: Creamy buttermilk-based curry from Karnataka. Cooling and perfect for hot days.

steps.instruction: Cook vegetable cubes until tender but not mushy.
Grind coconut with green chilies and cumin to a smooth paste.
Mix buttermilk with the coconut paste, turmeric, and salt.
Add cooked vegetables to the buttermilk mixture.
Heat gently without boiling. Remove from heat before it curdles.
Heat oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves. Pour over the curry.

tips: Never boil buttermilk - it will curdle
Use fresh buttermilk for best taste
Serve at room temperature or slightly warm

recipes.name: Ragi Dosa
recipes.description: Healthy finger millet dosa, a nutritious alternative to regular dosa. Popular in Karnataka.

steps.instruction: Mix ragi flour and rice flour with salt.
Add water gradually to make a thin, pourable batter.
Add finely chopped onion, green chili, cumin, and curry leaves.
Heat a non-stick tawa. Pour batter and spread into a thin circle.
Drizzle oil around edges. Cook until bottom is golden and crisp.
Flip and cook the other side. Serve hot with chutney.

tips: No fermentation needed
The batter should be thin for crispy dosas
Cook on medium heat for best results

recipes.name: Set Dosa
recipes.description: Soft, spongy dosas served in sets of 3-4. Perfect for soaking up curries and chutneys.

steps.instruction: Ensure batter is well fermented and slightly sour.
The batter should be thick, not thin like regular dosa batter.
Heat a tawa on medium heat. Do not make it too hot.
Pour a ladle of batter and gently spread into a 4-5 inch circle. Keep it thick.
Add ghee on top. Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
No need to flip. The dosa should be soft and spongy. Serve 3-4 per person.

tips: Don't flip the dosa - cook only on one side
The tawa shouldn't be too hot
Cover while cooking for soft texture

recipes.name: Vegetable Sagu
recipes.description: Creamy coconut-based vegetable curry. Classic accompaniment to set dosa and poori.

steps.instruction: Cook vegetables until tender but not mushy.
Grind coconut, poppy seeds, cashews, green chilies, and ginger with water to smooth paste.
Heat oil, add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add chopped onion and sauté until soft. Add tomato and cook until mushy.
Add turmeric and ground paste. Cook for 3-4 minutes.
Add cooked vegetables and water to desired consistency. Simmer for 5 minutes.

tips: The gravy should be creamy, not watery
Adjust spice to taste
Can add fried cashews for garnish

recipes.name: Badanekai Gojju
recipes.description: Sweet, sour, and spicy brinjal curry in tamarind gravy. A North Karnataka specialty.

steps.instruction: Cut brinjal into cubes. Soak in water to prevent browning.
Soak tamarind and extract juice.
Dry roast red chilies, coriander, and cumin. Grind with coconut to a paste.
Heat oil. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves. Add brinjal and fry for 5 minutes.
Add turmeric, tamarind juice, jaggery, salt, and ground paste. Mix well.
Cover and cook until brinjal is soft and gravy thickens.

tips: Balance sweet and sour to taste
The gojju should be thick, not watery
Tastes better the next day

recipes.name: Bassaru
recipes.description: Traditional toor dal sambar from Karnataka. Essential accompaniment for ragi mudde.

steps.instruction: Pressure cook toor dal until soft. Mash well.
Extract tamarind juice.
Heat oil, add mustard seeds, red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add tomato and cook until soft.
Add mashed dal, tamarind juice, sambar powder, turmeric, salt, and water.
Simmer for 10 minutes until flavors blend. Adjust consistency.

tips: The consistency should be slightly thick
Add more tamarind for tangier taste
Best served hot with ragi mudde

recipes.name: Huli Tovve
recipes.description: Mild and comforting dal preparation from Karnataka. Everyday staple in Kannadiga homes.

steps.instruction: Pressure cook dal with tomato and turmeric until soft.
Mash the dal well. Add water to get desired consistency.
Add grated coconut, jaggery, and salt. Simmer for 5 minutes.
In a small pan, heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, red chili, and curry leaves.
Add asafoetida and pour the tempering over dal.

tips: The consistency should be medium thick
Coconut adds subtle sweetness
Simple and perfect for everyday meals

recipes.name: Mangalorean Chicken Sukka
recipes.description: A dry, spicy chicken preparation from Mangalore with freshly ground coconut masala. The dish is known for its intense flavors and minimal gravy.

steps.instruction: Dry roast coriander seeds, cumin, peppercorns, and red chilies until fragrant. Cool and grind with coconut, tamarind, and garlic to a coarse paste.
Marinate chicken with turmeric and salt for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a heavy pan. Add sliced onions and curry leaves. Fry until onions are golden brown.
Add marinated chicken and cook on high heat for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the ground masala paste. Mix well to coat the chicken evenly.
Add a little water, cover and cook on medium-low heat until chicken is tender, about 20 minutes.
Uncover and cook on high heat until the masala is dry and coats the chicken. The oil should separate.

recipes.name: Kundapura Chicken
recipes.description: A fiery red chicken curry from Kundapura in coastal Karnataka. Known for its distinctive red color and spicy coconut-based gravy.

steps.instruction: Dry roast red chilies, coriander seeds, peppercorns, and fenugreek until fragrant. Cool completely.
Grind roasted spices with coconut, tamarind, garlic, and ginger to a smooth paste adding water as needed.
Heat oil in a pan. Add sliced onions and curry leaves. Fry until onions turn deep golden.
Add chicken pieces and turmeric. Cook on high heat for 5 minutes.
Add the ground masala paste and salt. Mix well.
Add 1 cup water, cover and cook on medium heat until chicken is tender, about 25-30 minutes.
Adjust consistency and seasoning. The curry should have a thick, coating gravy.

recipes.name: Goli Baje
recipes.description: Crispy, fluffy Mangalorean fritters made with maida and curd. A popular evening snack, especially during monsoons.

steps.instruction: Mix maida, rice flour, and salt in a bowl.
Add curd and mix well. Add water gradually to make a thick batter (like idli batter consistency).
Add finely chopped green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, and grated coconut.
Let the batter rest for 30 minutes. Add baking soda just before frying and mix gently.
Heat oil for deep frying. Drop spoonfuls of batter into hot oil.
Fry on medium heat, turning occasionally until golden brown and crispy all over.

recipes.name: Kadubu / Karnataka Idli
recipes.description: Steamed rice dumplings wrapped in turmeric leaves. A traditional Karnataka breakfast with a unique leaf aroma.

steps.instruction: Soak rice for 4-5 hours. Drain well.
Grind soaked rice with coconut, cumin, pepper, and salt to a coarse batter.
The batter should be thick, not runny. Let it rest for 15 minutes.
Clean turmeric leaves and wilt them slightly over a flame.
Place a portion of batter on each leaf and fold into a parcel.
Steam in an idli steamer or pressure cooker for 15-20 minutes until cooked through.

recipes.name: Kori Rotti
recipes.description: Iconic Mangalorean dish of spicy chicken curry served over crispy rice wafers. The rotti soaks up the flavorful gravy.

steps.instruction: Dry roast red chilies, coriander, cumin, and fenugreek seeds. Cool and grind with coconut, tamarind, and garlic to a smooth paste.
Heat oil in a pan. Add sliced onions and curry leaves. Fry until onions are golden.
Add chicken pieces and turmeric. Cook on high heat for 5 minutes.
Add the ground masala paste and salt. Mix well to coat the chicken.
Add 2 cups water. Cover and cook until chicken is tender and gravy thickens, about 25 minutes.
Break rice wafers into pieces and place on a plate. Pour hot chicken curry over them.

recipes.name: Udupi Sambar
recipes.description: Authentic temple-style sambar from Udupi. A perfectly balanced lentil and vegetable stew with aromatic spices.

steps.instruction: Pressure cook toor dal until soft. Mash well and set aside.
Dry roast coriander, cumin, fenugreek, and red chilies. Grind with coconut to a fine paste.
Cook vegetables with turmeric until tender. Add tamarind extract and jaggery.
Add mashed dal and ground paste. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Pour over sambar.

recipes.name: Halbai
recipes.description: Traditional Karnataka rice pudding sweet made with rice flour, jaggery, and coconut milk. A festive delicacy.

steps.instruction: Mix rice flour with 1 cup coconut milk to make a smooth paste without lumps.
Melt jaggery with a little water. Strain to remove impurities.
Add remaining coconut milk to jaggery syrup. Bring to a gentle boil.
Slowly add rice flour mixture, stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
Keep stirring on medium heat. Add ghee gradually as it thickens.
When mixture leaves the sides of the pan and ghee separates, add cardamom and fried cashews.
Spread on a greased plate. Cool, cut into pieces and serve.

recipes.name: Uppittu
recipes.description: Karnataka-style savory semolina porridge. A quick, wholesome breakfast staple in every Kannadiga household.

steps.instruction: Dry roast semolina until slightly golden and aromatic. Set aside.
Heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, and cashews. Fry until golden.
Add curry leaves, green chilies, ginger, and chopped onion. Saute until onion is soft.
Add water and salt. Bring to a rolling boil.
Reduce heat and add roasted rava slowly, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Cover and cook on low heat for 3 minutes. Garnish with coriander and serve hot.

recipes.name: Saagu
recipes.description: Karnataka-style creamy mixed vegetable curry with coconut and poppy seed paste. Perfect accompaniment for dosa and poori.

steps.instruction: Cut vegetables into small cubes. Cook until just tender.
Grind coconut, poppy seeds, cashews, green chilies, and ginger to a smooth paste.
Heat oil. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add chopped onion and saute until golden. Add tomato and cook until soft.
Add turmeric and ground paste. Cook for 3 minutes.
Add cooked vegetables and water to desired consistency. Simmer for 5-7 minutes.

recipes.name: Mysore Pak
recipes.description: Legendary sweet from Mysore made with besan, ghee, and sugar. Melt-in-mouth texture with a rich, buttery flavor.

steps.instruction: Sift besan to remove lumps. Heat ghee in a heavy pan and keep it warm on low heat.
Make sugar syrup by boiling sugar with water until it reaches one-string consistency.
Reduce heat to low. Add besan to the syrup and mix quickly without lumps.
Add ghee in batches (2-3 tbsp at a time), stirring continuously.
Keep adding ghee and stirring. The mixture will become frothy and start leaving the sides.
When ghee starts to separate and mixture is foamy, add cardamom and pour into a greased tray immediately.
Let it set for 30 minutes. Cut into squares while still warm.

recipes.name: Pathrode
recipes.description: Colocasia leaves stuffed with spiced rice and coconut paste, rolled and steamed. A traditional Mangalorean delicacy.

steps.instruction: Soak rice for 2 hours. Grind with coconut, red chilies, tamarind, coriander, cumin, turmeric, jaggery, and salt to a thick paste.
Wash colocasia leaves and pat dry. Remove the thick stem.
Place a leaf with the vein side up. Spread the rice paste evenly, leaving edges.
Stack 3-4 leaves with paste on each, then roll tightly from one end.
Steam the rolls for 20-25 minutes until cooked through.
Cool slightly, slice into rounds, and shallow fry until crispy on both sides.

recipes.name: Shavige Bath
recipes.description: Savory vermicelli upma, a popular Karnataka breakfast. Quick to make and flavorful with vegetables and spices.

steps.instruction: Dry roast vermicelli until light golden. Set aside.
Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Fry until golden.
Add curry leaves, green chilies, ginger, and chopped onion. Saute until onion is soft.
Add diced carrot, peas, turmeric, and salt. Stir for 2 minutes.
Add water and bring to boil. Add roasted vermicelli and mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat for 5 minutes until vermicelli is soft. Add lemon juice and garnish with coriander.

recipes.name: Bonda Soup
recipes.description: Unique Karnataka preparation where crispy bondas are served immersed in spicy, tangy rasam. A beloved Bangalore street food.

steps.instruction: Boil, peel, and mash potatoes. Add chopped green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, turmeric, and salt. Mix well and shape into small balls.
Make batter with besan, rice flour, turmeric, and water. It should be thick coating consistency.
Heat oil. Dip potato balls in batter and deep fry until golden brown. Set aside.
For soup: Blend tomatoes. Extract tamarind juice. Combine tomato puree, tamarind juice, rasam powder, salt, and 3 cups water. Boil for 10 minutes.
Heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, red chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Pour tempering over the soup.
Place bondas in serving bowls. Pour hot soup over them. Garnish with coriander and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Neer Dosa with Coconut Milk
recipes.description: A richer variation of the classic Neer Dosa made with coconut milk for extra creaminess. Delicate and lacy.

steps.instruction: Soak rice for 4-6 hours or overnight. Drain completely.
Grind soaked rice with coconut, coconut milk, water, and salt to a very thin, pourable batter.
The batter should be thinner than buttermilk. Strain if needed.
Heat a non-stick pan on medium heat. No oil or grease needed.
Pour batter from a height in circular motion, letting it spread into a lacy pattern naturally.
Cover and cook for 1-2 minutes. No flipping needed. The dosa will be white and soft.

recipes.name: Dry Chicken Ghee Roast
recipes.description: An extra-dry version of the famous Mangalorean Chicken Ghee Roast with intensified spices and more ghee for a richer taste.

steps.instruction: Dry roast all dried chilies, coriander, cumin, pepper, and fenugreek until very fragrant. Cool completely.
Grind roasted spices with garlic and tamarind to a thick paste using minimal water.
Marinate chicken with half the paste and salt for at least 1 hour.
Heat ghee in a heavy kadai. Add sliced onions and curry leaves. Fry until onions are deeply caramelized.
Add marinated chicken. Cook on high heat for 8 minutes, stirring to sear all sides.
Add remaining paste. Reduce heat, cover and cook until chicken is done, about 15 minutes.
Uncover and roast on high heat until completely dry and ghee separates around the masala.
